discussion.content:
Correct Answer: C. usermod ג€"a ג€"G dialout $USER

dialout group: Full and direct access to serial ports. Members of this group can reconfigure the modem, dial anywhere, etc.

questions.question_text: A user requested a USB serial device to be added to a desktop computer. The device has built-in kernel driver support. The administrator tested the device installation and access, but the user cannot access the serial port. Each time the user attempts to access the device, an error log is created that shows the user does not have permission to use the serial port. Which of the following will add a user to the group that has serial port capabilities?

A system ran out of storage space on a particular mount and will not allow anything to be written to disk. The df command shows there are 6GB free on the mount, and there is no inode exhaustion. This issue has happened before due to a known large log file that was not being rotated. The administrator remembers the file name but cannot remember the location of the log file or which process is writing to it. Which of the following would be the BEST solution to correct this issue while maintaining availability?

discussion.content: For me, best answer is "A". "df" shows space, but the storage is in fact ran out of space. This is usually due to a file that was deleted but a process is still has the file opened an it will not release the space until the process is killed or restarted. The first step to fix this issue is to find the process that is opening deleted files and "lsof" is the best tool to find that.
It should be A, the administrator doesn't remember which process is writing the file.

A is the right Answer from my point of view.
The lsof command stands for List Open Files and shows open files and which process uses them, while 
truncating (or emptying) a file would be in the case of log files, the process of clearing a bunch of old data from log files to make way for newer and up-to-date information, thereby making troubleshooting much easier.

Answer is A
We cannot delete file if some process use it but can truncate. It means that BC wrong.
D will just restart process and did not clean up file. We should clean up some free space somehow. And only A will works.

comments.content: Disregard, answer is D. rjpraz right. file was already clean up, but process still did not release it. In that case process restart will resolve the issue.

discussion.content: Disregard my comment, it is D
The Answer is B. You know the filename, but you don't know where it is, you would use the locate command to find the file by name.

choices.A: Use the lsof command to find where the large log file is located and truncate it
choices.B: Use the locate command to find where the large log file is located and delete it
choices.D: Use the ps command to find which process is writing to the log file, and then kill and restart the process
choices.C: Use the du command to find where the large log file is located and delete it

questions.question_text:
A Linux administrator suspects unauthorized users are attempting to log in to the Linux server remotely. Which of the following should the administrator check
FIRST?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: B. /var/log/secure

/var/log/secure

What’s logged?
RedHat and CentOS based systems use this log file instead of /var/log/auth.log. 

It is mainly used to track the usage of authorization systems.
It stores all security related messages including authentication failures.
It also tracks sudo logins, SSH logins and other errors logged by system security services daemon.

questions.question_text: A user receives an access_denied error when trying to modify a file, even though the file permissions are set to 777. Which of the following commands should be used to view additional file permissions?

A junior administrator needs to unload an older video kernel module.
Which of the following commands would BEST accomplish this task?

discussion.content: Although the rmmod command can be used to unload kernel modules, it is recommended to use modprobe -r instead.

C - rmmod command will definitely remove the module . modprobe will remove the module as well, but only by running the command as modprobe -r , so I go with option C which is rmmod.
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/rmmod-command-in-linux-with-examples/

Selected Answer: C
the questions says unload, not remove dependencies. Also the modprobe command is not complete so it is rmmod.
To unload a kernel module, we use the rmmod (remove module) command.

rmmod is a trivial program to remove a module (when module unloading
 support is provided) from the kernel. Most users will want to use
 modprobe(8) with the -r option instead.
The question does say commands. Was this supposed to be multiple choice? If so, rmmod and modprobe.
modprobe preferred over insmod and rmmod commands.

comments.content: rmmod will not remove dependencies, wile modprobe -r will.

discussion.content:
rmmod will remove the module as requested.

modprobe will do the same, but you will have to add the -r switch
